p: Melissa officinalis L., also known as lemon balm, English balm, garden balm, balm mint, common balm, melissa, sweet balm, and heart‚Äùs delight, is an aromatic herb from the mint family (Lamiaceae) that includes two subspecies: Melissa officinalis L. subsp . officinalis, the common cultivated lemon balm, and Melissa officinalis L. subsp. altissima, naturalized in New Zealand and known as bush balm. The first information about the usage of the plant was found in Greece, 2000 years ago. In 2007, Khare [ 231] published the results that the plant has antidepressant, antispasmodic, antihistaminic, and antiviral properties and can be used in cases of anxiety, neurosis and nervous excitability, palpitation and headache, and also in hyperthyroidism.
